section.hand:
To S
r
Ed. Norreis May 5 1592

page.lettertext:
fol.195r
May To S
r
Edward Norris From M
r
Bodly
S
r
to
e self same effect as yor l
re
doth request
[.]
for
e furderance of
e cause my
L. Treasurer
hath
[written]
very earnestly unto mee. To whom to tell yo
u
truly
[I]
did signify againe, what had moved mee of late to forb
[eare]
from any dealing in any action of yo
urs
: not for want of
[.]
good affection to
s
ve yo
r
turne in any thing, but bec
[ause]
I found that of yo
r
self I was not rightly und
r
stoode, &
[.]
of yo
r
friend
a great dele woorse: who had medled
[in]
matters not fit for theyr medling & don mee greater
wrong, then they could answere w
th
theyr credit. Neverthel
[es]
besides that his L. mighte command me in any thing
[.]
the unfained love
t
I had borne to yo
r
self above others
was redy to forget any former unkindenes. Wheruppon I
shall request yo
u
that as yo
u
finde mee in my deeds
& by trew information, & not by glavering report
of yll ministers about yo
u
so to constrew my proceeding,
& not to be
swaded that seing I have affected yo
u
as much as any whoseoever of yo
r
greatest welwillers
not for any benefit or hope of any benefit, but in
regard of yo
r
vertue & yo
r
honorable conversation
I will not now be wonne to hurt yo
u
& in a matter
that doth neither advantage nor concerne mee. Heer
is nothing yet resolved about sending for yo
u
hether
or sending any unto yo
u
. For they are so buisied
about theyr
s
vices toward
as they will hearken to
nothing els. But if I were as you I would se[nd]
them a curteous letter, & p
r
tend where you are yo
r
[.]
excessive charg
, &
e necessity of yo
r
p
r
sence in
[t]
place of
t
goverment, & so de
te. For then
[in]
yo
r
absence & winning of time I shalbe able to
[do]
somwhat for
e ending of these quarrels to yo
r
bett
[er]
contentation,
& so I bid yo
u
for this p
nt
most
hartely farewell. 4 May 1592.
